item.title: Updates: U.K. Prepares for New Era After Queen’s Death
item.description: King Charles III will return to London and address the nation on Friday afternoon. The country now enters a mourning period that continues until after her funeral.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96; Was Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
item.description: She ruled for seven decades, unshakably committed to the rituals of her role amid epic social and economic change and family scandal.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2012.

item.title: Long an Uneasy Prince, King Charles III Takes On a Role He Was Born To
item.description: Once an awkward, self-doubting young man, he comes to the throne, at 73, as a self-assured, gray-haired eminence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: As heir to the throne, Charles took on several of the queen’s duties in recent years. In May, he delivered the Queen’s Speech during the state opening of Parliament.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Comes at Moment of Uncertainty for Britain
item.description: There is no analogous British figure who will be mourned as deeply, or whose death will provoke a greater reckoning with the identity and future of the country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2018.

item.title: Operation London Bridge: What Happens After Queen Elizabeth’s Death
item.description: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has set in motion a meticulously choreographed process — known as Operation London Bridge — that the palace, and the nation, has spent decades planning.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II waved from the balcony of Buckingham Palace in 1953 after her coronation. She was Britain’s longest-reigning monarch.

item.title: Grief for the Queen Mixes With Criticism of the Monarchy
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II was remembered by ordinary Britons, world leaders and other royals for her grace, humor and longevity. Others had more conflicted views on the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside the British Embassy in Washington on Thursday after the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: A Life in Photos
item.description: Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, and became Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. Here are a selection of images from her life.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mona Boshnaq
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: A Kick at the Door, a Knife in the Hand: The Saskatchewan Murders
item.description: As investigators pore over a sprawling and complex trail of crimes, a clearer picture is emerging of the stabbing rampage on an Indigenous reserve in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Claims Significant Gains Against Russia on Multiple Fronts
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky says Kyiv has “liberated” more than a thousand square kilometers of territory this month.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for food distribution at a destroyed apartment complex in Chernihiv, northern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Liz Truss, New UK Leader, Lays Out Energy Price Cap Plan
item.description: Facing severe economic headwinds, Prime Minister Liz Truss announced emergency measures to freeze gas and electricity rates.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss campaigned on a message of tax cuts and deregulation, which made the price freeze a striking ideological reversal.

item.title: Iraq’s Instability Deepens Amid Political Paralysis and Clashes
item.description: Politicians have failed to form a new government nearly a year after the last elections. Baghdad just saw its worst militia clashes in years. And despite vast oil wealth, the state can’t provide basic services.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:description: The Central Bank of Iraq, designed by the renowned Iraqi-born architect Zaha Hadid, under construction on the banks of the Tigris River in Baghdad.

item.title: China’s Zero-Covid Approach Explained as Chengdu Lockdown Is Extended
item.description: The country where the coronavirus first emerged is committed to going to great lengths to stop its spread.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing in Beijing last month. Others may debate whether China’s approach to controlling the virus goes too far, but its leaders are staying with it.

item.title: Macron Aims for a National Dialogue in France, but Faces No-Shows
item.description: The inaugural meeting of a council to examine France’s most pressing problems had an issue of its own: boycotts.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France waxed poetic on a rugby field where Thursday’s meeting took place, saying the new committee would change the country in a profound way.

item.title: Philippines Rebuffs International Court Over Duterte’s War on Drugs
item.description: The Marcos government rejected a request to let prosecutors resume an inquiry into former President Rodrigo Duterte’s drive against crime, which left thousands dead.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Former President Rodrigo Duterte, who left office in June, faced broad accusations of brutality in his war on drugs.

item.title: Volker Türk, an Austrian Diplomat, Takes U.N. Human Rights Post
item.description: One of Volker Türk’s toughest challenges will be determining what to do about a highly critical report on China that his predecessor, Michelle Bachelet, released just before departing.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Volker Türk, 57, is not widely known outside the United Nations, but he was seen as the front-runner in a field of 13 candidates interviewed for the role.

item.title: For Australians, Too, It’s the End of an Era
item.description: “I don’t think we’ll ever have the security again that we had with her,” said one Australian about the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Laying flowers for Queen Elizabeth in Canberra on Friday.

item.title: Premier League Soccer Games Are Postponed Out of Respect for the Queen
item.description: The league was one of many sports organizations in Britain to alter its schedule after the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Players for Manchester United observed a moment of silence in honor of Queen Elizabeth II before their match on Thursday night.

item.title: Filthy Plane Videos Ignite Debate About Airline Cleanliness
item.description: Recent social media posts suggest that the days of clean flights may be going the way of masks. And they’ve ignited a debate about who bears responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: Kim Jong-un Says North Korea Will ‘Never Give Up’ Its Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The law authorizes a nuclear strike if an enemy tries to remove Kim Jong-un from power, the North’s state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, said Thursday that there would “no longer be any bargaining over our nuclear power,” according to state media, which released this photo.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: The One Constant in an Inconstant World
item.description: From fading empire to the Cold War to 1970s turmoil to Brexit to Covid, “she was always there.” What will Britain, and the world, do without her?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip amid memorial bouquets at Buckingham Palace in 1997, the year Princess Diana died.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A special edition of the Briefing on the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in the Throne Room at Buckingham Palace in June 1953, after her coronation.

item.title: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
item.description: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine and rising energy prices are rapidly overturning European economic orthodoxy, with barely a peep of dissent.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, at a Siemens Energy plant in Muelheim an der Ruhr, last month.

item.title: Meghan and Harry’s children could now inherit royal titles.
item.description: Now that their grandfather is king — and if the royal family adheres to convention — the children of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex should become Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, during the queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations in London in June.

item.title: In a Divided Britain, Near Unity in Admiration of the Queen
item.description: Across London, conversations reflected how deeply the loss had touched the nation — and how fundamental Elizabeth’s role had been in the national identity.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Saskia Solomon, Emma Bubola and Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Queen Elizabeth II in Piccadilly Circus in London on Thursday.

item.title: The Queen Met 13 Sitting U.S. Presidents, Who Basked in Her Global Prestige
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II was a gracious host and guest over the last seven decades, even when faced with protocol mistakes and awkward missteps.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle in 1982.

item.title: Biden and Former Presidents Give Statements on Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: Six of the American leaders she met during her long life offer remembrances of her and their encounters.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96
item.description: Plus the Solomon Islands postpones its election and tycoons leave China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Eddie Mulholland/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/AFP Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-serving monarch in British history.

item.title: Blinken’s Surprise Visit to Ukraine Offers Aid and Encouragement
item.description: At a “pivotal moment” as a counteroffensive makes gains, the secretary of state pledged $2.8 billion more in military aid to Ukraine and allies.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting the devastated city of Irpin during his surprise trip to Ukraine Thursday.

item.title: 9 Books About Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: Elizabeth, famously reticent during her decades in the public eye, was a source of fascination for many. These books offer a deeper understanding of her life, family and world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Mourning Queen Elizabeth II, in Photos
item.description: The death of the queen marks the loss of a revered monarch, the only one most Britons have ever known.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Chris Jackson/Chris Jackson Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A rainbow emerged as the Union Jack flag was lowered following the news of the death of Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday at Windsor Castle.

item.title: President Biden Remembers Queen Elizabeth II Who ‘Defined an Era’
item.description: Biden first met Queen Elizabeth in 1982 during a trip to Britain as a young senator. His most recent meeting came about a year ago, in Cornwall, England.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Queen Elizabeth II last year at Windsor Castle outside London.

item.title: Britain’s National Anthem Will Become ‘God Save the King’
item.description: Many small changes are expected in Britain in the coming weeks, but one will be only obvious only when it’s sung: For the first time since 1952, the anthem will go ‘God save the king.’
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Oxford Street in London decked out in May for Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.

item.title: Hurricane Kay Veers Close to Baja California’s Western Coast
item.description: Kay is the closest hurricane to hover near Southern California in more than two decades, the National Weather Service said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: Strong waves coming ashore before the arrival of Hurricane Kay in Los Cabos, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: Conditions at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Get ‘Worse and Worse and Worse’
item.description: Cut off from the country’s electric grid, the plant is relying on an emergency measure that it is not designed to keep up for long, the head of Ukraine’s national energy company said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petro Kotin, the chief executive of Energoatom, Ukraine’s state nuclear power company, said the conditions at the Zaporizhia plant are deteriorating.

item.title: Olivia Colman and Claire Foy on Playing Queen Elizabeth II on ‘The Crown’
item.description: In “The Queen” and “The Crown,” actors took different approaches to get under the skin of the enigmatic monarch.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Olivia Colman in her Emmy Award-winning portrayal of Queen Elizabeth II in Season 3 of “The Crown.”

item.title: Failure to Slow Warming Will Set Off Climate ‘Tipping Points,’ Scientists Say
item.description: As global warming passes certain limits, dire changes will probably become irreversible, the researchers said, including the loss of polar ice sheets and the death of coral reefs.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A summer sunset over Disko Bay in Ilulissat, Greenland.

item.title: How Queen Elizabeth II’s Style Shaped the World
item.description: The longest-serving British monarch let her clothes do the talking for her.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II inspecting a guard of honor during her Silver Jubilee visit to Scotland in 1977.

item.title: Where Is Balmoral Castle?
item.description: Her family says Queen Elizabeth is happiest at the sprawling estate, her primary summer residence.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Balmoral Castle in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, about 100 miles north of Edinburgh.

item.title: CIA Director Said Putin’s Ukraine Invasion Looks Like a ‘Failure’
item.description: William J. Burns said that counterattacks in the south and northeast showed that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had underestimated Ukraine’s capacity for combat.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing to fire toward Russian positions in the Kharkiv region in July.

item.title: Captured UK Aid Worker Paul Urey’s Body Shows Signs of Torture, Ukraine Says
item.description: Paul Urey was charged with mercenary activities by a pro-Russian separatist group, which claimed he died in July from illness and stress.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Paul Urey, a British aid worker, was detained by pro-Russian forces in April at a checkpoint near Zaporizhzhia while working to evacuate civilians.

item.title: Covid’s Toll on Native Americans
item.description: Covid’s death toll in Indigenous communities has no modern precedent.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez and Ashley Wu

item.title: Climate Change Could Worsen Supply Chain Turmoil
item.description: A drought that has crippled economic activity in southwestern China hints at the kind of disruption that climate change could wreak on global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A drought in China has had ripple effects for businesses around the globe.

item.title: Fire at a Karaoke Bar in Vietnam Kills 32
item.description: An electrical problem set off the latest in a string of fatal blazes at entertainment venues in the country.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen
item.media:credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A fatal fire started on the second floor of An Phu Karaoke in Binh Duong Province, Vietnam.

item.title: Solomon Islands’ Leader, a Friend of China, Gets an Election Delayed
item.description: The prime minister claims the country can’t afford to hold national elections next year. His opponents see a power grab linked to Beijing’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare of the Solomon Islands in 2019. He said the postponement of national elections “does not in any way inhibit or prohibit the right to vote.”

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Vladimir Putin’s energy influence in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin said he would meet in person with Xi Jinping in Uzbekistan next week.

item.title: In Ukraine, a Beekeeper Hunkers Down With His ‘Frontline Bees’
item.description: With nearby sunflower fields unplanted and rockets overhead, a Ukrainian’s bees ventured toward the battlefront and returned with a bumper crop.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Even as the war encroached, Petro Fedorovych, a beekeeper, stayed in his small village of Bohdanivka. “I built this house with my hands,” he said. “I will never leave.”

item.title: Putin Dismisses Losses in Ukraine, Says Russia Is Gaining From War
item.description: Defiant against the West and despite the heavy blows to his economy and military, President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia had “not lost anything” from its invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylyov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media showing president Vladimir V. Putin addressing the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok on Wednesday.

item.title: On Brazil’s Bicentennial, Bolsonaro Softens Campaign Rhetoric
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro called his supporters and the military to the streets to celebrate Brazil’s 200th anniversary. Then he softened his campaign tone.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro on Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro. In two speeches to supporters, Mr. Bolsonaro moderated his rhetoric and focused on what he cited as his accomplishments.

item.title: Egypt Files Criminal Charges Against 4 Journalists Over One Article
item.description: After a dominant political party tied to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi filed complaints against them, the journalists were charged with publishing fake news, among other counts.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Lina Attalah, the founder and editor of Mada Masr, was one of four journalists charged on Wednesday in Egypt.

item.title: Anne Garrels, Fearless NPR Correspondent, Dies at 71
item.description: She reported on conflicts around the world and for a time was the only American broadcast journalist reporting from Baghdad during the U.S. “shock and awe” bombing campaign in 2003.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping Likely to Meet
item.description: Plus India’s growing economy and China’s “zero-Covid” trap.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would meet in person with President Xi Jinping of China in Uzbekistan next week.

item.title: Truss Forms a Cabinet Diverse in Background but Not in Ideology
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, has recruited cabinet members from diverse backgrounds, though her inner circle retains a hard Conservative edge.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Liz Truss’s cabinet met for the first time on Wednesday, a day after she took over as the new prime minister.

item.title: The Baltic States agree to bar land crossings by Russian tourists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: More than 900,000 Russians have entered Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Finland since the start of the war in Ukraine, mainly through land border crossings like the one in Terehova, Latvia.

item.title: A Chimpanzee Escaped From a Ukrainian Zoo. She Returned on a Bicycle.
item.description: The adventures of Chichi the chimpanzee were shared widely on social media, delighting residents of Kharkiv, a city that has faced ceaseless bombardment by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy

item.title: Lawmakers Press Biden to Track U.S. Aid Tied to Civilian Harm in Yemen
item.description: Democrats and Republicans want the administration to do more to ensure that American military aid to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates does not contribute to civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Yemenis dig graves for children killed when their bus was hit during a Saudi-led coalition airstrike in 2018.

item.title: Putin and Xi to Meet as Russia Moves Closer to China
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would meet in person with President Xi Jinping of China in Uzbekistan next week.

item.title: Arab States Demand That Netflix Drop ‘Offensive Content’
item.description: Egypt joined six Gulf Arab nations in insisting that streaming services take down programs that go against “societal values.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Netflix is under fire from the governments of Egypt and several Gulf countries for promoting content that runs counter to their “societal values.”

item.title: How to Save a Forest by Burning It
item.description: Prescribed burns are key to reducing the risk of catastrophic wildfires. Scientists are using high-tech tools to ensure they can be done safely in a warming world.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Andri Tambunan
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
